reviewText: These were released when I was in high school. My favorite is Twelfth Night which does not appear to be here - I only hope the list is wrong. However, A Midsummer Night's Dream with Helen Mirren as Titania is fantastic and it is well worth purchasing this collection to see her in that role. All of these plays were quality productions and I have waited over 20 years to be able to see them again.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have seen all of these plays done by other actors, producers, directors, and what have you, and I can say that with one big exception, with these five plays, other performances are more engaging, more alive, and more dramatic, but to varying degrees. This is especially true of "A Midsummer Night's Dream", which may be the most widely performed of Shakespeare's comedies (albeit perhaps not his best.) The best part of Shakespeare's play, the Mechanicals subplot, is the weakest part of this film, especially the performance of Bottom, the role with the most number of lines in the play.Diametrically opposite to this weakness is the strength of John Cleese's performance as Petruchio in "The Taming of the Shrew", directed by Jonathan Miller, the producer of all the other films. Cleese is a magnificent comic actor, and he brings it all to the performance, however he is not adequately matched by the actress performing his "Kate". To see well balanced performance of these two characters, watch the Burton and Taylor version.This comparison brings up the fact that the technical qualities of the films is "fair" at best. I suppose they were shot in color, but the color barely shows. It would have been better if they were shot in a high quality black and white film.Another interesting contrast in this set is between "The Tempest" and "The Merchant of Venice". The former play is lead by Michael Hordern, a premier Shakespearean actor, at the right age for the part, but both he and his supporting cast seem to lack "spunk". In contrast, the cast of "...Merchant" seems just right, even though there is no major name among the cast.I was also not fond of the performance of "As You Like It". As Shakespeare goes, this play seems the least fraught with some danger for some cast members. It is mostly "nice". Even "Much Ado About Nothing" has dire threats lurking in the plot. Therefore, it seems the cast has to work harder to bring the play to life. It seems they did not work hard enough. Even Helen Mirren was not enough to spark strong emotions (To see Helen Mirren really heat up Shakespeare, see her performance in "The Tempest" from 2010.)So, I liked two performances (Taming and Merchant), and found one (Midsummer) in the middle, and did not like two (As You Like It and The Tempest). If you are on a tight budget, these are a great deal. But, except for Cleese' performance, they tend to be average.
summary: Great bargain, not the best presentations
Title: N/A

reviewText: Shakespeare's comedies fared better than many of the other plays in the BBC Shakespeare series from the late 1970s and early '80s.  The histories were very hit and miss, with the Henry VI plays being done abysmally.  Some well-regarded actors overacted (Anthony Quayle's famous Falstaff was too big for the small screen);  while others were barely there (David Gwillim's Henry V).  On the other hand, the tragedies were workmanlike enough, though dragged down by the heavy baggage of the Hamlets, MacBeths and Lears gone by.  And Anthony Hopkins' Othello may be the single worst performance of the entire series.While Shakespeare's breezier comedies were uniformly excellent, this collection is not.  How did they have the nerve to leave out MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING, with Cherie Lunghi's Beatrice and Robert Lindsay's Benedick?  Sure, the later movie was pretty good, but I prefer Lunghi's reading of "If I were a man!"  Or the BBC's top-notch TWELFTH NIGHT, with Felicity Kendal's Viola being the object of desire of Sinéad Cusack's Olivia?  While neither of these stagey productions are as slick as the later (and more famous) movie versions, they were, like other comedies, done quite well.  As two of Shakespeare's best comedies, it's a shame they were left out of this set (unless they were going to put out a vol. 2 that never materialized).So what are we left with?  Actually, several solid plays.AS YOU LIKE IT starring Helen Mirren (acting her heart out as Rosalind, though she may be a tad too well-endowed to be believable as a boy), with Angharad Rees as a fetching Celia.  Though some scoff at the ability to pull off this play in an actual forest setting, this version, set out in the open, works fine (until the unfortunate, wince-inducing introduction of Hymen).  Also, you get to see David Prowse (briefly) at work without his Darth Vader mask.THE TAMING OF THE SHREW is unjustly maligned these days, usually because it's taken out of its original framing sequence so critics who don't know as much as they think they do can't see this knockabout farce in context.  Director Jonathan Miller leaves out the framing sequence himself, but provides us a heartfelt performance from his Petruchio (Monty Python's own John Cleese);  while Sarah Badel's Kate is more than able to keep up with him.  This may be the definitive SHREW on DVD.A MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM is not quite on par with LIKE IT or SHREW, though the wonderful Helen Mirren is back as Titania.  Most performances are good, but Brian Glover's Bottom should have been cropped back.  Apart from Glover's overacting, the only trouble with this DREAM is the play within a play, which rarely works.  Still, this one's a keeper.Then we come to the bottom of the list.  Like Shakespeare's tragedies, THE TEMPEST has too much baggage, though Michael Hordern was an inspired choice as Prospero.  It's hardly a gay farce like the others, though perhaps the makers of this set were trying to provide a representative sample of Shakespeare's breadth.Finally, we come to THE MERCHANT OF VENICE, a play difficult to stomach these days, on many levels.  It probably should be moved out of the "comedy" section of Shakespeare and added to the "Problem Plays."  Nevertheless, it is one of Shakespeare's most famous plays and it has some of his best (and more familiar) lines.  (btw, a better, or just as good, MERCHANT appears in the "MAGGIE SMITH AT THE BBC" collection with Frank Finlay as Shylock and Charles Gray as Antonio).Overall, excellent acting.  Adequate production values (these are filmed plays with low budgets, not smoothly-running and edited movies of the post-Branagh era).  It is a shame they were unable (or unwilling) to include two of Shakespeare's brighter comedies, TWELFTH NIGHT or MUCH ADO, in the place of the autumnal TEMPEST and the problematical MERCHANT.  But the set must be judged by what is there, rather than what isn't.  And this set has enough good stuff to please any Shakespeare fan.For the money, however, for the real Shakespeare fan it might be cheaper in the long run to do as I did, invest in a region-free DVD player and buy the PAL boxed set of all the plays in the series.
summary: Five Stars or the Films, Not for the Set

reviewText: This boxed set was a gift. Of the five plays presented therein, four: As You Like It, Merchant ..., ... Shrew and Tempest are defective, playing well for the first couple acts and then dissolving into all manner of pixels, black bands, freeze frames, and frustration.  Looking at some of the other reviews of the series, I see the same complaints. Maybe the problem lies in a particular pressing and has subsequently been corrected.  In any case, BEWARE!

reviewText: This is the BBC series marketed by Ambrose Video that many colleges and libraries have purchased (see ambrosevideo.com).  These DVD packages are a very good deal because the original videos are prohibitively expensive (although I broke down and purchased several of the plays that are simply not available on any other media - when was the last theater run you saw of Cymbeline, Henry VIII, or Troilus And Cressida?).  The 37 play VHS series is still >$2,500, the DVD series ~$3,000, selected 5 play sets on DVD $150, and individual plays around $100.  The series was remarkable in that it actually included all 37 plays in full with a solid set of players (many famous) who worked hard at maintaining as much historical accuracy as possible, but especially with the verbiage.This set makes a total of 15 of the plays now available at reasonable cost on DVD.  There are 3 five play DVDs now available as follows:TragediesRomeo & JulietHamletMacbethJulius CaesarOthelloHistoriesHenry VRichard IIRichard IIIHenry IV, Part IHenry IV, Part IIComediesAs You Like ItThe Taming of the ShrewThe TempestA Midsummer Night's DreamThe Merchant of VeniceThe Comedies Series has some of the best, so it is well worth the expense.  The problem is that many of the scenes are less than sparkling....it's very much like watching the filming of the series of plays instead of watching a movie or TV version.....even the Bard himself would have struggled to keep the life in them with no audience.  Sometimes the effort for accuracy actually shows in some of the acting.  You have to give the various troups credit for sticking to the goals of the series, but realize that it is done with some sacrifices to the thrill and magic at some points.What I like about the BBC series is the hard-to-find plays.....like All's Well That Ends Well, Coriolanus, Cymbeline, Measure For Measure, Henry VI, Henry VIII....it's nice to see the whole Wars Of The Roses historical series with the same troup.Here is the information on each play in this series (as given by Ambrose Video):As You Like ItShakespeare at his sunniest, posing serious questions in the most lighthearted tone. Is there a natural difference between a Duke's daughter and a commoner? Are men really stronger than women? Or is it just society's role? Some of these characters briefly discard the roles they've played, while others adopt new one. All learn something about themselves. Stars Helen Mirren, Brian Stirner and Richard Pasco.  Running Time: 150 minutes.The Taming of the ShrewThis comic confrontation between the sexes is one of the most frequently-staged plays. Its sparkling wit and rich characterization are matched with an outstanding cast.  John Cleese, of Monty Python and Fawlty Towers gives a portrayal of Petruchio that wins unanimous critical acclaim, praised as "an object lesson in serving Shakespeare to a present-day audience. ̈ Running Time: 127 minutes.The TempestA dramatic romance, weaving fancy and realism into a plot that speaks to audiences today. This timeless stage is set on an enchanted island, where an exiled Duke and two young lovers encounter the occult, finding good and evil in their own natures. Starring Christopher Guard, Michael Hordern and more.  Running Time: 150 minutes.A Midsummer Night's DreamThree plots intertwine: the entangled love affairs of Demetrius and Helena, Lysander and Hermia, the comic performance of a "play within a play" by the tradesmen of Athens and the antics in fairyland of King Oberon and Queen Titania. The strong cast features  Helen Mirren and Peter McEnery, Pippa Sward, Brian Clover and Phil Daniel. As the New York Times states "they are all accomplished performers, but the director has given the extra dimension of using them brilliantly in terms of television."  Running Time: 112 minutesThe Merchant of VeniceThe Merchant of Venice is one of Shakespeare's most famous comedies. It has become most celebrated for its captivating villain, Shylock. Blending tragedy and comedy, this play presents contrasts and ambiguities. The complexity lies in the character Shylock. Is he a villain, a buffoon or tragic hero?  Starring: Warren Mitchell, Gemma Jones.  Running Time: 157 minutes
summary: Five More Of The Ambrose Series!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought all Shakespeare BBC  series... Of course, had no time to watch all discs in a timely manner. One of the disks (so far) freezes and would not play. I contacted AMBROSE VIDEO PUBLISHING and they say that since the set was not bought from them directly, most likely is a illegal copy so they will not replace it.The DVD is most likely original (I can tell a DVD-R from an original) but it will not play.On one hand, AMBROSE VIDEO PUBLISHING wants to increase the sales by using Amazon but on the other hand will offer NO support from purchase made outside their site (if even this is true).Other customers complain also about this kind of problem. Frankly, until this DVD, it never occurred to me to find an original, brand new DVD that would not play.I suggest avoiding their stuff...$150 per a 5 DVD set is not cheap so if I pay them money, the least I expect is that the DVD would play.
summary: Poor quality of the DVDs, bad attitude from AMBROSE VIDEO
